If this year's strike against war
approaches the proportions of strikes
in the past, approximately three
hundred students will walk out of
class next Thursday at 10:00 o'clock.
All over the country students will be
protesting war on the same day.
Meanwhile, at a meeting of the
Permanent Peace council held last
Tuesday, advocates of the two-speaker program

won their point and

changed previously arranged plans.
The program now calls for two nonstudent speakers—one to present collective security and the other, isolation as a means of preserving peace.
Collective security advocates on the
Peace council have secured Dr Henry
Sigerist, a member of the Hopkins
Medical school and a proponent of
socialized medicine. Isolationists have
secured Mr Harold Bosley, minister
of the Mt Vernon Methodist Episcopal church.
Two student speakers, included on
the program as a part of the original
plan, will still be included but their
speaking time will be shortened. Murray Kempton, chairman of the Peace
council, will be one of the student
speakers; the other one has not yet
been chosen. In their talks, the student speakers will emphasize the effect of war on youth.
Ben Courtwright, who is not a
members of the Peace council, will act
as chairman at the strike.

Handbook work begins
The organization of the staff
of the Hopkin's Student Handbook has gotten underway with
the election of Jeff Hamilton as
editor and Don Kirkwood as business manager. A meeting of candidates for the staff was held
April 11, and work on the publication is expected to be underway soon.

music of the Townsmen.

Refugee committee
$80 short of goal
Over $670, or less than $80 short
of the goal sought has been pledged
or paid in cash in the drive to raise
living expenses for a German refugee students, $486 in cash is in a
strongbox in the Treasurer's office,
guarded night and day by Texas
rangers.
All who have pledged, but have not
paid in their subscriptions, are asked
to do so immediately by sending in
checks or cash to Wethered Barroll,
jr, treasurer of the refugee committee, Post Office Box Number 33.
The committee, headed by Harold
Ricards, feels the campaign, which
began in February, is a success and
is now considering candidates for
presentation to Dean Berry for consideration for the refugee scholarship.

Significant changes in the College
of Arts and Sciences were announced
early this week with the publication
of the university circular. Under the
new orga.nization a pre-medical
group takes its place as one of the
four divisions within the college,
while students looking forward to
law now have a specific program of
courses suggested.
Formerly a division of the natural
science group, the new pre-med body
was formed as an answer to a long
need here at the Houpins. In the past,
students preparing for medicine did
not have the advantages of a definite
program, but were expected to conform to the requirements of the larger group. Thus courses taken were
sometimes superfluous but more often
were insufficient preparation for specialized studies. This arrangement
was particularly inadequate as the
Hopkins has more than her share of
pre-medical students.

Similar reasons necessitated the
advent of pre-law advice. The new
plan, however, does not divorce this
body from the social science group,
but merely recognizes it as a well
defined part of that group.
Other changes in the college include an addition to the graduation
requirements. Along with the comprehensives, seniors in the natural
science or pre-med groups will be
expected to present an original essay before a science seminar. This
system, which has seen great success in other schools, is intended to
foster thinking and individuality.
Many courses have 'also been added
to next year's role. Included among
them are quantitative analysis, advanced expository writing, problems
of philosophy, political parties and
public opinion, current problems of
the Orient, and a political science
seminar.

June Week committee awaits answers from
bands previously contacted in student poll

It was reported that tours for all the bands are being arranged now
and that
if these bands are to be contracted, action must be taken within the
next
ten days.
Virginia, Pennsylvania, VMI, Washington & Jefferson, and Duke
are
all booking bands now, the representative stated. It is believed that Hopkins will have to obtain the pledges
immediately. He asserted that the
Pennsylvania Ivy ball, which is a traditional dance at the University of

"The BSA has nothing to do with

on the Poll seemed to indicate. It is
distinctly a seperate organization."

The campus awoke to political life again this week with the nominations
of Carrington Williams and Frank Butt for Student council presidency. The
election will be held on April 24.
Both candidates advanced a five point platform asking for some further
modified reform to bring activities more under control of the campus.
The field still remains open for additional nominations. lithe proposed
council re-organiz.ation goes through, there will be three senior positions
on the Council.

With an emphatic and unequivocal
"No!" the Student Activity Committee, headed by Herbert Rydstrom,
cancelled the Spring Barnstormer
presentation of The Petrified Forest this week. The reason vouchsaped • to unsatisfied Barnstormer
officers was that numerous social
affairs occurring the week preceeding, and the week-end of the show,
May 13, would probably prevent students from lending their financial
support by purchasing tickets.
John E Desch, director of Barnstormer successes in the past, had
been engaged as director for the
show; business, publicity, and production staffs were already busily at
work, and the first tryouts had been
scheduled when S A C flatly refused
to consider any appropriation justified. Dean Berry, approached for his
sanction before work had begun, had
given his permission to proceed, contingent upon the attitude of the S
A C.
Unconfirmed reports made campus
rounds to the effect that at least two
full-length plays will be offered next
academic year, one of which will be
dramatic, rather than arcial. This
would be a radical departure from
the usual Barnstormer custom of givdng, in the past five years, a cycle of
comedies including: Once in a Lifetime, Boy Meets Girl and She Loves
Me Not.
'Observers, criticizing Barnstormer
officials, claim that the lateness of
the decision to put on the production, made it unfeasible from the
start. The fact that the new officers,
Tom Powers, president, Alfred Agrin,
business manager, and Robert Minkus, production manager, were not
inducted until just before the Easter
vacations, is used in explanation of
the delayed start.

New members were elected to the

Everyone of the new members has

ability.

The committee in charge, headed
Lavertnick, made no an-

nouncement concerning the price of

been signed and that further details

Phi

Beta Kappa
taps new men
Twenty-seven
Hopkins students
were tapped by Phi Beta Kappa, oldest intercollegiate honorary fraternity, at the organization's annual business meeting last Monday. The announcement came last Wednesday
from George Evans, retiring secretary of the organization.
College students admitted were
John Streett Baldwin, Gilbert Blum,
Stanley Lorman Blumenthal, John
Wesley Chambers, Robert Kaye, Herman Keival, Arthur A Maass, Joseph
Charles Matchar, Henry Musnick,
Henry P. Porter, jr, Howard Norman Seal, Daniel Joseph Stoneld
Albert Frederick Strobel, and Jacob
Earl Thomas, jr.
The honorary fraternity selects collegiate and graduate students during
the final year of study for high scholarship during their course as candidates for the AB, PhD, and MD degrees.
The officers of the chapter for 193940 were also elected. President, Dr
Joseph T Singewald, jr; vice-president, Dr E V McCollum; secretary,
Dr George H Evans, jr; treasurer,
Dr Alsoph H Corwin.
The newly elected members will
be initiated on April 28, at the Johns
Hopkins club on the Homewood
campus with Edward P Chaney of
the University of Pennsylvania as
speaker, the annual dinner of the
chapter will be held on the same evefling.

If, after due consideration (and it must be considered), the Council decides that the System is to be
carried on, immediate steps must be taken to provide
for a clearer definition of the role each group is to
play in the effecting of its proper working. This is
something that must be completed by this year's Council and not left to hang over. The lame duck session
about to start should complete this unfinished business

Even though we consider
the competition afforded the
Hopkins' Lacrosse team to
date as mightily meagre, we
must admit that the 66
points scored by the boys in
their three starts indicates
power. And we do remember that the Blue scored only
about 10 points against CCNY last year, which fact
indicates some sort of improvement in the Lacrosse
being dealt out here abouts.
And in spite of the actuality of Hopkins defense
men being forced to seek their exercise in attack positions during intercollegiate competion, we feel inclined

Tomorrow's game in enemy territory will prove to
some extent whether or not our hopes have foundation.
Swarthmore did beat us last year, and will certainly try
their darndest to repeat. We think we can beat better
than Swarthmore.

FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1939

The Peace ,Strike is next
Thursday.
There is much to say, yet
little left to say. Obnoxious
propoganda and harangues
eace
and diatribes have assailed
us these many months. Heart-sick and worried, we
have watched the world march on its merry way to
hell.
If we're serious, let's make the strike for peace a
sincere demonstration of what and how we feel. If
not, let's stay away—a circus is not in order.
We are offered the choice of fighting the tide—and
losing, perhaps; but fighting—or drifting shamefully
with it.

The Barnstormers' maneuverings of the last few
weeks, with their final letdown, has left us nothing
short of disgusted. They
have absolutely no excuse
for disappointing the cam-

The unfortunate combination of an unpropitious
date and a misunderstanding of responsibility of the
SAC by the club leaves room for plenty of buck-passing.
But the fact remains that if the boys had been on their
toes right after their first money-making show, arrangements could have been completed and the show ready
for production this week or next.
Too, the Club had no right to definitely announce
a show while the possibility of veto existed. No word,
or a simple report of investigative activity would have
sufficed pro tem.
Well, next year's show should be a whopper with
the cash reserve on hand. But for the present we're
left with a bad taste.

Gratifying indeed was the
appearance Monday of
printed statements of intention by the Messrs. Williams
and Butt, candidates for the
Student Council presidency.
The matter is reprinted in

another part of this issue.
Substantially, the programs are similar. Both men
take a stand for continuation of the referendum and
recall measures; the reorganization amendment providing for representation reapportionment; extension
of student self-government.
• Frank Butt adds to the foregoing, support of the
BSA and intensive concentration of energies toward
the furthering of the Honor system. Carrington Williams has frowned on compulsary assemblies and has
come out for a pre-election statement from all candidates on policy.
It is significant that at no point do the platforms
conflict. It would seem that such problems as do face
the Council are apparent to both candidates. An analysis and selection of either man on this basis is still
most difficult. Perhaps later developments before the
election date will aid voters in making their choice.
Both men deserve credit, however, for having had
the courage, or energy, or initiative to present their
prospecti. We hope to be able to discuss them more
specifically as to merit before election day rolls around.
Meanwhile, candidates' for senior representative
could well follow suit. The NEWS-LETTER and billboard are still available, but the deadline's fast approaching. Next to the president, the senior representation has usually been most important in Council
activity.
The president is powerless without his Council's
support, and students must elect representatives whose
programs are coincident if action is anticipated. Statements of policy become, therefore, ever more important.
At long last the Honor
commission is tendering its
complete report on the present functioning of the Honor
system to the Council. Today the Council will be able
to begin a detailed analysis
of the figures and facts presented, preparatory to unddertaking some definite action.
When the Commissions were set up last year what
they were to do was pretty clear to the incumbent Council. Exact definition of their functions seems to have
been lost in the shuffle this year. The net result has

B assumes"unity" plea of Student union
a weak pretext to limit free speech
THE PEACE committee had a lively
meeting recently to fight out the
policy of the coming strike. The most
interesting, because significant, occurrence was a baldly totalitarian
suggestion by an ASU-YCL delegate;
'because the world situation is so upset, he said, we must at all costs have
unity. The large minority of students
who favor isolationism therefore
should be silenced, unrepresented at
the strike, so that the present communist party line of "collective secuirity" may be forced on everyone. This
‘astonishingly bare-faced attempt to
suppress opposition on a weak pretext of emergency clearly reveals the
nature of the blended organizations
which proposed it through their
spokesman. Of course, in a true emergency, free speech may become dangerous, but only a Bolshevik dares
say that freedom of debate must immediately be curtailed in America
merely because Hitler threatens the
Ukraine.

Chairman Weggie Barroll
is retracting words uttered
in haste and bitterness these
days. With the funds for the
Refugee drive reaching a
total of about six hundred
dollars, the culmination of
weeks and months of desperate effort is shining thfough
the clouds of discouragement.
The whole business assumes a rosy robe of sentimentality when viewed in retrospect. Somewhere in
strife-tom, crazy Europe right now there is a desperate
youth, shortly to be made happy by the magnanimity
of hundreds of persons thousands of miles away.
Some of the students reaction was most regrettable,
however. Undergraduate intolerance is a sad business
at best. But at the Hopkins, steeped in a tradition of
freedom, it has no place. In fact, today's very society
allows no room for this type of reaction.
The faculty comes in for more than its share of
praise. Many of them contributed to an extent far
and away beyond their means. Here, at least, in the
men we must daily meet, is offered a lasting inspiration.
All things considered, more might have been done, but
what little has been accomplished is something of
which to be proud.

Last Lap
of the
Refugee Drive

The Shining Light of
Zealousness emerged from
the Soda Fountain one day
after having his daily Lemon
Phosphate and said it's
Spring. It's really Spring.
The Magnolias are in Bloom
and the Engineers have shed their overalls and
everything.
Suddenly he noticed several men, pushing a Roller
over a lot with white stripes on it. Oh, goody, said the
Sloz, the tennis courts. They're being rolled.
Oh, but it's no use. Those Boys with the Big Clodhoppers will probably be tramping all over it in No
Time At All, and that'll be the End of It. And the boys
at school will probably be crowded off them anyway.
What lack of consideration!
So the Sloz shrivelled up and died.

around five thirty, and the matinee
performance had just been concluded.
Walking to their dressing rooms
were five

charming

young ladies,

chattering along the way about the
painful condition of their feet. And
interesting conditions they were indeed. Especially that of the darkhaired, stately-looking woman in the
midst of the group. She, in particular
was bemoaning the way the toe of
her right foot was behaving. As she
approached her dressing roim, we
noticed that the attractive individual was none other than Katherine
Cornell.
While backstage the one thing that
stood out above all others was the
absolute informality. The stage hands
run around from one set to the other,
greet the performers by first names,
and in general, treat them as though
they were no one of any particular
importance. In turn the members of
the cast walk around half made-up,
some in costume, others in shirt
sleeves, kidding with the workmen,
conversing with each other while
puffing on a cigarette—but above all
—maintaining an atmosphere of
general friendliness.
One actor in particular is noted
for kindness and informality with his
l associates. He is John Barton, whom
we had the pleasure of interviewing
when he appeared in this city with
the show "Tobacco Road." Clearly
do we remember how he strolled off
the stage after one of. the performances, and although tired, dirty,
and covered with piles of grease
paint and artificial whiskers, he stopped to smoke a cigarette with one of
-the attendants near the set.
If we missed a tete-a-tete with
Katherine, at least we had a glimpse
behind the backdrop. The legitimate
stage showed itself unchanged. In
spite of the radical changes that it
has undergone in the past decade, it
has still managed to uphold the traditions that it has been noted for since
its existence—informality, geniality,
and kindness.—A. Reisfeld.

The Johns Hopkins tennis team,
under the guidance of Capt William
Lamble and Manager Leroy Applefield, opened its 1939 campaign in
a blaze of glory in downing a good
Albright college team 5 to 4.

The spirited Johns Hopkins baseball team opened their 1939 campaign and christened their new diamond in gala fashion Wednesday afternoon when they completely swamped Wilson Teachers of Washington
17 to 1. The Jays will entertain Drew university Saturday at 3:30 on the
new diamond behind Levering hall.
Some 100 fans of the national past-time braved a high cold wind to
watch the first baseball game in the history of the Hopkins to be played
on the Hopkins campus.
Coach Bob Owings started Donohue, ace pitcher who is said to be
even better than B Miller of last
year, on the mound with veteran
Lew Schwartzman behind the plate.
Callahan was on first, Salvia at
second, freshman Didusch at shortstop, and Capt Milt Alperstein on
the keystone sack, rounded out the
infield. Hoffman was in left field,
Bateman patrolled center and Westermeyer started in right field.
Walks Two
"Ball one," blurted out the umpire
as Donohue let fly the first ball which,
just missed the outside corner, and
though he walked the first two batters, he put out the next three in
order to retire the sides.
The outcome was never in doubt
as Didusch, first Jay batter, drew a
pass. Westermeyer sacrificed him to
second on a good bunt and was safe
when the catcher threw high to
first. Bateman bunted to make the
bases loaded and Callahan brought
Bateman home on a bunt and run
play.
Alperstein Hits First
Capt Alperstein got the first hit of
the ball game when he got a whistling single over shortstop. And as the
mess was untangled the Jays had
four runs to their credit before they
were retired.
Donohue had things well in hand
the entire game pitching two hit ball
and issuing only four passes while
his mates were collecting eleven hits
off Hart, the opposing pitcher.
Milberg, who went in on the
mound for Hopkins in the 6th appeared to have even more stuff than
Donohue as he struck out four of the
eight men to face him and pitched
no-hit ball. Coach Owings hb,s a. good
starting pitcher in Milberg who has
improved greatly over last year.
Alperstein Leads Hitters
Capt Alperstein led his cohorts in
the slugging, getting three for four.
Salvia hit the longest hit of the day,
a tremendous clout over the center
fielder's head on which he only got
three bases as he failed to touch
third.
The team looks great this year
and Hopkins is due for it's best season in years. Coach Owings was well
satisfied with the Jays showing.

I R C sponsors movie
before crowd in Latrobe
film "From Tsar to
Lenin," vividly pictures
Russian events
A capacity audience crowded Latrobe hall last Tuesday to see From
Tsar to Lenin, a historical film shown
under the auspices of the history department and the International Relations club.
Tracing the struggles of the Russian people from the days Nicolas II
to those of Soviet supremacy, the
picture told the story of the revolution by means of shots taken by the
Tsar's

official

photographer, news-

reel men, and adventurers. The film
was edited by Max Eastman.
Mr Eastman also supplied the running comment. In his introductory remarks, Dr Eric Goldman warned the
audience that, Mr Eastman, an outstanding Socialist theoretician, was
inclined to favor the early Bolsheviks
but disapprove of the Stalin regime.
The showing of From Tsar to
Lenin coincided with the study of
the Russian revolution in sophomore
history classes.
First portrayed was the contrast
in the days of the autocracy between
imperial splendor and starvation. In
the rise of the Provisional government, Kerenski, Miliukov, and Lvov
were featured.
With shots of Russian disasters
during the war, Mr Eastman described the popular swing leftward
and the rise of the Soviet. Many
Communist leaders, such as Lenin,
Trotsky, and John Reed were shown
action. The film included a
in
glimpse of Stalin.
A graphic description of the postwar struggles against White and
Allied armies emphasized Kolchak's
slaughter of workers and soldiers
and the eventual triumph of Trotsky's Red army.

If this year's strike against war
approaches the proportions of strikes
in the past, approximately three
hundred students will walk out of
class next Thursday at 10:00 o'clock.
All over the country students will be
protesting war on the same day.
Meanwhile, at a meeting of the
Permanent Peace council held last
Tuesday, advocates of the two-speaker program

won their point and

changed previously arranged plans.
The program now calls for two nonstudent speakers—one to present collective security and the other, isolation as a means of preserving peace.
Collective security advocates on the
Peace council have secured Dr Henry
Sigerist, a member of the Hopkins
Medical school and a proponent of
socialized medicine. Isolationists have
secured Mr Harold Bosley, minister
of the Mt Vernon Methodist Episcopal church.
Two student speakers, included on
the program as a part of the original
plan, will still be included but their
speaking time will be shortened. Murray Kempton, chairman of the Peace
council, will be one of the student
speakers; the other one has not yet
been chosen. In their talks, the student speakers will emphasize the effect of war on youth.
Ben Courtwright, who is not a
members of the Peace council, will act
as chairman at the strike.

Refugee committee
$80 short of goal
Over $670, or less than $80 short
of the goal sought has been pledged
or paid in cash in the drive to raise
living expenses for a German refugee students, $486 in cash is in a
strongbox in the Treasurer's office,
guarded night and day by Texas
rangers.
All who have pledged, but have not
paid in their subscriptions, are asked
to do so immediately by sending in
checks or cash to Wethered Barroll,
jr, treasurer of the refugee committee, Post Office Box Number 33.
The committee, headed by Harold
Ricards, feels the campaign, which
began in February, is a success and
is now considering candidates for
presentation to Dean Berry for consideration for the refugee scholarship.

Significant changes in the College
of Arts and Sciences were announced
early this week with the publication
of the university circular. Under the
new orga.nization a pre-medical
group takes its place as one of the
four divisions within the college,
while students looking forward to
law now have a specific program of
courses suggested.
Formerly a division of the natural
science group, the new pre-med body
was formed as an answer to a long
need here at the Houpins. In the past,
students preparing for medicine did
not have the advantages of a definite
program, but were expected to conform to the requirements of the larger group. Thus courses taken were
sometimes superfluous but more often
were insufficient preparation for specialized studies. This arrangement
was particularly inadequate as the
Hopkins has more than her share of
pre-medical students.

Similar reasons necessitated the
advent of pre-law advice. The new
plan, however, does not divorce this
body from the social science group,
but merely recognizes it as a well
defined part of that group.
Other changes in the college include an addition to the graduation
requirements. Along with the comprehensives, seniors in the natural
science or pre-med groups will be
expected to present an original essay before a science seminar. This
system, which has seen great success in other schools, is intended to
foster thinking and individuality.
Many courses have 'also been added
to next year's role. Included among
them are quantitative analysis, advanced expository writing, problems
of philosophy, political parties and
public opinion, current problems of
the Orient, and a political science
seminar.

The campus awoke to political life again this week with the nominations
of Carrington Williams and Frank Butt for Student council presidency. The
election will be held on April 24.
Both candidates advanced a five point platform asking for some further
modified reform to bring activities more under control of the campus.
The field still remains open for additional nominations. lithe proposed
council re-organiz.ation goes through, there will be three senior positions
on the Council.

With an emphatic and unequivocal
"No!" the Student Activity Committee, headed by Herbert Rydstrom,
cancelled the Spring Barnstormer
presentation of The Petrified Forest this week. The reason vouchsaped • to unsatisfied Barnstormer
officers was that numerous social
affairs occurring the week preceeding, and the week-end of the show,
May 13, would probably prevent students from lending their financial
support by purchasing tickets.
John E Desch, director of Barnstormer successes in the past, had
been engaged as director for the
show; business, publicity, and production staffs were already busily at
work, and the first tryouts had been
scheduled when S A C flatly refused
to consider any appropriation justified. Dean Berry, approached for his
sanction before work had begun, had
given his permission to proceed, contingent upon the attitude of the S
A C.
Unconfirmed reports made campus
rounds to the effect that at least two
full-length plays will be offered next
academic year, one of which will be
dramatic, rather than arcial. This
would be a radical departure from
the usual Barnstormer custom of givdng, in the past five years, a cycle of
comedies including: Once in a Lifetime, Boy Meets Girl and She Loves
Me Not.
'Observers, criticizing Barnstormer
officials, claim that the lateness of
the decision to put on the production, made it unfeasible from the
start. The fact that the new officers,
Tom Powers, president, Alfred Agrin,
business manager, and Robert Minkus, production manager, were not
inducted until just before the Easter
vacations, is used in explanation of
the delayed start.

FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1939

The Peace ,Strike is next
Thursday.
There is much to say, yet
little left to say. Obnoxious
propoganda and harangues
eace
and diatribes have assailed
us these many months. Heart-sick and worried, we
have watched the world march on its merry way to
hell.
If we're serious, let's make the strike for peace a
sincere demonstration of what and how we feel. If
not, let's stay away—a circus is not in order.
We are offered the choice of fighting the tide—and
losing, perhaps; but fighting—or drifting shamefully
with it.

The Barnstormers' maneuverings of the last few
weeks, with their final letdown, has left us nothing
short of disgusted. They
have absolutely no excuse
for disappointing the cam-

Gratifying indeed was the
appearance Monday of
printed statements of intention by the Messrs. Williams
and Butt, candidates for the
Student Council presidency.
The matter is reprinted in

another part of this issue.
Substantially, the programs are similar. Both men
take a stand for continuation of the referendum and
recall measures; the reorganization amendment providing for representation reapportionment; extension
of student self-government.
• Frank Butt adds to the foregoing, support of the
BSA and intensive concentration of energies toward
the furthering of the Honor system. Carrington Williams has frowned on compulsary assemblies and has
come out for a pre-election statement from all candidates on policy.
It is significant that at no point do the platforms
conflict. It would seem that such problems as do face
the Council are apparent to both candidates. An analysis and selection of either man on this basis is still
most difficult. Perhaps later developments before the
election date will aid voters in making their choice.
Both men deserve credit, however, for having had
the courage, or energy, or initiative to present their
prospecti. We hope to be able to discuss them more
specifically as to merit before election day rolls around.
Meanwhile, candidates' for senior representative
could well follow suit. The NEWS-LETTER and billboard are still available, but the deadline's fast approaching. Next to the president, the senior representation has usually been most important in Council
activity.
The president is powerless without his Council's
support, and students must elect representatives whose
programs are coincident if action is anticipated. Statements of policy become, therefore, ever more important.
At long last the Honor
commission is tendering its
complete report on the present functioning of the Honor
system to the Council. Today the Council will be able
to begin a detailed analysis
of the figures and facts presented, preparatory to unddertaking some definite action.

they were to do was pretty clear to the incumbent Council. Exact definition of their functions seems to have

THE PEACE committee had a lively
meeting recently to fight out the
policy of the coming strike. The most
interesting, because significant, occurrence was a baldly totalitarian
suggestion by an ASU-YCL delegate;
'because the world situation is so upset, he said, we must at all costs have
unity. The large minority of students
who favor isolationism therefore
should be silenced, unrepresented at
the strike, so that the present communist party line of "collective secuirity" may be forced on everyone. This
‘astonishingly bare-faced attempt to
suppress opposition on a weak pretext of emergency clearly reveals the
nature of the blended organizations
which proposed it through their
spokesman. Of course, in a true emergency, free speech may become dangerous, but only a Bolshevik dares
say that freedom of debate must immediately be curtailed in America
merely because Hitler threatens the
Ukraine.

spite of the radical changes that it
has undergone in the past decade, it
has still managed to uphold the traditions that it has been noted for since
its existence—informality, geniality,
and kindness.—A. Reisfeld.

The Johns Hopkins tennis team,
under the guidance of Capt William
Lamble and Manager Leroy Applefield, opened its 1939 campaign in
a blaze of glory in downing a good
Albright college team 5 to 4.

The spirited Johns Hopkins baseball team opened their 1939 campaign and christened their new diamond in gala fashion Wednesday afternoon when they completely swamped Wilson Teachers of Washington
17 to 1. The Jays will entertain Drew university Saturday at 3:30 on the
new diamond behind Levering hall.
Some 100 fans of the national past-time braved a high cold wind to
watch the first baseball game in the history of the Hopkins to be played
on the Hopkins campus.
Coach Bob Owings started Donohue, ace pitcher who is said to be
even better than B Miller of last
year, on the mound with veteran
Lew Schwartzman behind the plate.
Callahan was on first, Salvia at
second, freshman Didusch at shortstop, and Capt Milt Alperstein on
the keystone sack, rounded out the
infield. Hoffman was in left field,
Bateman patrolled center and Westermeyer started in right field.
Walks Two
"Ball one," blurted out the umpire
as Donohue let fly the first ball which,
just missed the outside corner, and
though he walked the first two batters, he put out the next three in
order to retire the sides.
The outcome was never in doubt
as Didusch, first Jay batter, drew a
pass. Westermeyer sacrificed him to
second on a good bunt and was safe
when the catcher threw high to
first. Bateman bunted to make the
bases loaded and Callahan brought
Bateman home on a bunt and run
play.
Alperstein Hits First
Capt Alperstein got the first hit of
the ball game when he got a whistling single over shortstop. And as the
mess was untangled the Jays had
four runs to their credit before they
were retired.
Donohue had things well in hand
the entire game pitching two hit ball
and issuing only four passes while
his mates were collecting eleven hits
off Hart, the opposing pitcher.
Milberg, who went in on the
mound for Hopkins in the 6th appeared to have even more stuff than
Donohue as he struck out four of the
eight men to face him and pitched
no-hit ball. Coach Owings hb,s a. good
starting pitcher in Milberg who has
improved greatly over last year.
Alperstein Leads Hitters
Capt Alperstein led his cohorts in
the slugging, getting three for four.
Salvia hit the longest hit of the day,
a tremendous clout over the center
fielder's head on which he only got
three bases as he failed to touch
third.
The team looks great this year
and Hopkins is due for it's best season in years. Coach Owings was well
satisfied with the Jays showing.

squad met and conquered their first

Although the visiting Gothamites

strong the Jay squad will be when
they meet Army and Princeton was

The New Yorkers came here with
an unbeaten record, but the home
team was much the faster, handled
the ball better, and seemed to have

visitors excelled only in their fancy
football checking dives, since a group
of their football stars were in their
starting lineup.
Missing numerous shots in the first

range. As the shots poured in the
City College goalie Mendlesohn, who
showed flashes of some fancy tending, began missing, and by the end
of the quarter Hopkins had scored
six points.
Fred Passano, veteran goalie, was
replaced after the first few minutes
by Toy Swerdloff, when Coach Morrill realized that the visitors would
offer no scoring threat.
Swerdloff played a bang up game
at the netting made some good stops,
and showed good form in scoring the
ball, when in the need of exercise.
The CCNY team shot their first
goal in the third period on a freak
shot by Yohel, seemed attackmen,
which rolled off his stick, banged a
few Jay players and then exclusively
went into the net.
Ed Spillman led the attack for
Hopkins with five goals to his credit,
while Murnaghan, Enders, and Penniman followed with three each.
Nance and Checkett scored two
apiece, with Green, Thomas, Melvin,
and Sheer getting single scores.

I R C sponsors movie
before crowd in Latrobe
film "From Tsar to
Lenin," vividly pictures
Russian events
A capacity audience crowded Latrobe hall last Tuesday to see From
Tsar to Lenin, a historical film shown
under the auspices of the history department and the International Relations club.
Tracing the struggles of the Russian people from the days Nicolas II
to those of Soviet supremacy, the
picture told the story of the revolution by means of shots taken by the
Tsar's

official

photographer, news-

reel men, and adventurers. The film
was edited by Max Eastman.
Mr Eastman also supplied the running comment. In his introductory remarks, Dr Eric Goldman warned the
audience that, Mr Eastman, an outstanding Socialist theoretician, was
inclined to favor the early Bolsheviks
but disapprove of the Stalin regime.
The showing of From Tsar to
Lenin coincided with the study of
the Russian revolution in sophomore
history classes.
First portrayed was the contrast
in the days of the autocracy between
imperial splendor and starvation. In
the rise of the Provisional government, Kerenski, Miliukov, and Lvov
were featured.
With shots of Russian disasters
during the war, Mr Eastman described the popular swing leftward
and the rise of the Soviet. Many
Communist leaders, such as Lenin,
Trotsky, and John Reed were shown
action. The film included a
in
glimpse of Stalin.
A graphic description of the postwar struggles against White and
Allied armies emphasized Kolchak's
slaughter of workers and soldiers
and the eventual triumph of Trotsky's Red army.

veteran, and former student at Glascow university and Trinity college,

groups the world over as a man who
knows their problems, their language,
and their concerns. This is his second visit to America.
